segments.text: Graduated from A&M in 1935 and went to teach in San Gabriel.
In two years' time, I left to go to Alfie, but I had one of the most remarkable experiences that I ever had in San Gabriel.
The secretary of the school board and I were absolutely like twin sisters.
And he had a history that I'd like to write his biography, but I can't get my own written.
But Jamie Clark was the secretary of the school board, and he approached the people by saying, WPA is building schoolhouses, and we can get a grant to build a schoolhouse.
So he asked the people,
to vote a $5,000 bond to build a schoolhouse.
Had the architects draw up an eight-classroom gymnasium-type schoolhouse, 256 feet long and 50 feet wide and with a gymnasium on the back.
And after it got started,
He barely got the foundation laid.
He didn't quite get it all finished before he had to have another bond issue.
And by the time he got the second bond issue, while we got the walls up top of the level of the ground, and we had to have another.
And I said, Jamie, you knew that you couldn't build a schoolhouse for what you have gotten so far.
He said, well, yes, I know.
But he said, my son asked me for a nickel one morning.
And then he asked me a nickel after breakfast.
And he asked me for a nickel.
He said, at the end of the day, he said, Daddy, here's this $0.25 I asked you for.
And so he got enough money to build a schoolhouse.
And I was put in charge of the laying of the rock on that schoolhouse.
And I spent more time.
somebody else took my responsibility so that I just had vocational agriculture and schoolhouse.
And when we had gotten that wall that was ten feet underground and eighteen feet above the ground and two pieces of girders that were sixty-six inches, sixty-six feet, two inches tall ready to be
joined by bolts in the center of the arch.
And when those were raised, there wasn't a plow in the field in San Gabriel when I told them when we'd raise the girders for the gymnasium.
And I want you to know that whenever that first girder went up there and went down into those bolts that were 18 inches in that stone wall,
And then lift let it down on the other side and it went down.
And it did so because I had enlarged the 8.
5H hole.
The two 5H holes together so that I had 10 inches on each end.
And when we raised those four girders in less than two hours.
I could have walked off of that top of that house without touching a thing but air until I got to the ground.
There was a 20-year-old individual in charge of a project that was employing 75,000, 75 people.
I was really a happy young man, I guarantee.
Now, go ahead.
Describe what it was like to...
What were your classes, and describe the students then.
The students that we had at the high school were farm people.
There were three different ethnic groups in the community.
There were Czechs, there were Germans, and then there were white folks.
And they were so designated.
And Jamie and I were the only people that could get along with all three ethnic groups.
And I wanted to take a German boy to the state contest in debate one time.
And I went to see the daddy of the boy and asked him if he could go with us.
And he said, well, yes, I reckon he can go.
But said, all you're doing is teaching him to run around, and I've got to teach him to work.
That's his attitude.
One man, when I took him home, he lived up on the hill, and it wasn't gravel.
And I took the boy home at night, 10 o'clock.
And the boy got into his parents' yard, and his dad heard something out there, and he got his shotgun and shot his son full of bullets.
Buckshot?
Buckshot.
And I want you to know that they took him to Temple and he wasn't fatally injured and so forth.
But I was afraid of that man ever since then.
You were responsible for teaching what courses?
Well, I taught a seventh class one semester.
And then at one time I taught a fifth grade class for one semester.
And the rest of the time I was teaching vocational agriculture and working on the building.
And the people in the ag education department told me that I either had to quit building the schoolhouse or, and I got a job at Alvin.
During those years at San Gabriel and then in Alvin,
What clearly were the rules of behavior and conduct for a young teacher?
They may not have been written down, but what did you know?
They clearly were that you had no contact of any kind with the students.
I had a girl that was a sophomore, and she brought roses to me every day.
And when I went back to one of the reunions 40 years later, one of the girls said, well, every girl in the class had a crush on you.
But remember, I still looked like I was 19 years old.
And I wasn't much older than that, but I knew better.
What about things like movies and smoking and dancing?
We were so far apart.
a way that we didn't have those things.
We were strictly a rural community.
And I had a rule that the boys could not smoke in the back seat of my car.
And if they had to smoke, they'd have to ride in the front seat with me.
Was it all right for you to smoke as a teacher?
Yeah, it did.
It was at that time.
I turned down one job when I was out on the interview because of school.
They asked me if I'd quit smoking if I got the job.
And I said, no.
I said, every one of you got a cigarette tray in front of you, and you asked me to say if I'd quit smoking, I will have your job.
And that was Riesel, Texas.
Could you go to a pool hall?
No.
Were you expected to be a churchgoer?
I didn't really feel like.
that there was any compunction, but I was.
But you didn't think that that was a requirement?
That's right.
And you went then to Alvin.
Describe those years.
Well, the first two years I was unmarried, and I got involved with Future Farmers there.
Finally, we
We had two projects that we were interested in.
One of them was a Jersey cattle business, and we bought Jersey cattle from R.E.
Hildebrandt in San Antonio, Jersey cash for our club, and he gave us a Jersey bull.
And then we bought pigs from former Governor Ross Sterling.
And at that time, the governor was using his help to have a sausage route.
And I was told that he made his living peddling whole hog sausage in Houston.
That Jesse Jones had caused his financial
empire to collapse because Jesse Jones told him to do something in Texas from Washington, and he said, I'm governor of Texas.
But he was a real interesting individual.
My boys were delighted to know that they'd been at the home of the ex-governor of Texas.
I took a group of boys one time to the Fort Worth Fat Stock Show with their livestock.
And when we were there, I had told them specifically that not one of them could get drunk when they were out with me, and some of them did.
And when I got back to Alvin and reported to the superintendent what had happened, he didn't uphold me in the decision that I had made, that I had explicitly told him.
was a part of their trip.
And so that's when I decided to get out of school teaching.
And I spent
from June 1st to October 1st on R.E.
Hildebrandt's dairy farm.
Now, this is what year?
Now, then that fall, what did you do?
I was in the Army.
I went into the Army on October 13th, 1941.
Where were you when you heard the news of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor?
I was in church with a friend of ours from Columbus, Georgia, who had relatives in Montgomery, Alabama, and they didn't have any transportation, so I took them to visit their relatives
And we went to church in Montgomery, Alabama, about 80 miles from Columbus.
And when I heard about the attack after our noon meal, I took off immediately to go back to the barracks in Fort Benning.
And what did you and your fellow officers and enlisted men think was going to happen?
Well, now, then I was living in an officer's barrack.
We had no contact with enlisted men until... What did you and your fellow officers do?
We went around and holding up our orders, and it said, unless sooner relieved, you will go back to your civilian occupation.
And then everybody looked at everybody else and said, you know what that means?
And that means we'll be in here a long time.
I had a fantastic career at the infantry school.
I went over there as a first lieutenant.
Since I had been a teacher, they kept me to be an instructor at Fort Benning.
And within five months after I started my instruction, I was promoted to captain.
And nine months later, I was promoted to major.
When I left there, that was the last promotion I had till I was discharged as Lieutenant Colonel.
And how long were you at the infantry school?
Two years.
I went in and took one course.
And then when I was relieved of my responsibility, I spent a period of time there till I got my majority.
And then I went to the field grade officer's class and spent two
nearly a year of my time there.
All right.
After that, where were you?
I went to Brownwood.
Camp Bowie.
Camp Bowie.
I was sent to Camp Bowie to be cadre for the new Corps after the 8th Corps moved out of Brownwood.

and whenever we interviewed the provost marshal there were four majors and of the four majors he said where did you come from where'd you come from where'd you come from where'd you come from what did you do before then i was the one who had been at fort benny as a small arms instructor and then the
The provost marshal said, well, who's the senior officer?
And then he said, well, let's not look at that.
He said, we've got one man here with experience in handling arms, so he'll be in charge of this group.
And we never knew who was the ranking officer.
Four majors, and I was in charge.
After being there a month,
the 8th Corps was to move out and we were to be in the 18th Corps.
And on Saturday, before the Corps was to move out Sunday morning, I was called in and offered the job of headquarters company commandant to go to Europe with 8th Corps.
And I said to the

chief of staff do i have to take it and he said well no and i said well look you people have known for 30 days that you were going overseas and you've prepared your family and you've taken your shots and you've done all of these things necessary and i said if i have to do everything in one day that you've had 30 days to do i won't be able to see my wife have i got it the
opportunity to decline.
It had been a great assignment.
But my wife and daughter was out there that I wouldn't see.
And I said, well, I just am going to turn it down because I don't want to leave my wife and daughter stranded out there.
And so I didn't go with them.
When the 18th Corps was activated,
I went out to Wachuga, came back Christmas.
And I'd been friendly with a fellow that was in Wachuga with me, Wirtz and I.
And three days after we got back from Wachuga, Wirtz was field officer of the day.
And a request came in for field grade officers to go
on an overseas assignment.
And before I got there, he had volunteered my name and his name to go on this foreign assignment.
Now, who is this?
A fellow by the name of Wirtz.
W-E-R-T-Z?
Yeah.
And Wirtz and I were together until we got to India.
So you leave Camp Bowie?
We left Camp Bowie.
On the 3rd or 4th of January, and within five days, I reported to Camp Meade in Maryland.
And then to India?
We stayed in Camp Meade in Maryland for nearly three months.
And I went back home after we'd been there two or three weeks and had been processed.
They said, if you've got any leave, why...
you can take leave now.
And I took 15 days leave and went back home about the end of February, first of March.
And by the way, when I went back home on that leave, we ordered another baby in our family.
And I didn't know my wife was pregnant until I got the overhand in Africa.
And when I found out about it,
I wrote back, well, I knew it was going to happen because every palm tree in Orianne had a stork on it.
And we stayed in Orianne for quite a long time.
And then we went on to Africa, and I was field officer of the day on two occasions, going across the Atlantic.
And then when they left Orianne, it was five days later until my turn came up.
And the interesting thing, as far as I'm concerned, is the fact that there were four men that I outranked.
And 245 that outranked me.
But one of them was, can't get the name.
It'll come to him in a minute, maybe.
But he later came home
and was in Eisenhower's cabinet as one of the Army cabinet members.
And then after he left the cabinet, he was president of the University of West Virginia.
And in one of the last issues of a magazine I got, he wrote a letter saying that we were liaison officers.
but nobody has written anything about the liaison officers.
I hope somebody does.
That was in one of the last issues that I had.
Elvis J. Starr was his name.
S-T-A-R-R. S-T-A-R-H. R-H, okay.
Elvis J. S-T-A-R-H. And?
I really wouldn't recognize the man today if I saw him, but I knew who he was when we were going.
So you go to Africa, then to India?
Right.
On the trip from O-Ran, we found an American soldier in the medical corps who was a native of China who was sent to
America to study art.
And the government said, we don't need any more art.
You go to University of Wisconsin and study engineering.
Very fluent in both English and Chinese.
And the stupid Americans sent him to China not as an interpreter, but as a medical corps man.
And from the time we left Oran until we got to Bombay, we studied Chinese two times a day.
We didn't know we were going to China until we were halfway across the Atlantic.
And when we opened our stuff going across the Atlantic, we found a Chinese language book there.
And that told us where we were going.
And we had a man on the board this year who was a principal from some
town in Newark, and he taught us contract bridge.
I played a lot of auction bridge when I was in A&M, but he taught us contract bridge so that I got two things on the trip from Oran to Bombay, how to play contract and how to speak Chinese.
And I
In all of my writings, I use a lot of Chinese terms, many of them which I've forgotten.
And much of the material that's in my memoir about World War II is refreshing of my memory by the letters that I wrote my wife.
Now, when did you arrive in China?
I was posted with the 64th Regiment
as a regimental liaison officer on the 22nd of June, 1944.
And that was the same time I got a job at San Gabriel at $90 a month.
And whenever the combat was over and we were put back in the forest in reserve, a lieutenant colonel came out there and took charge of it.
And he was left out there till it was ready to go back in combat
And they replaced him, and I took back my job as regimental.
But I was a battalion liaison officer when he was in regiment.
But as soon as it got time to move out, he didn't go into combat.
Right.
Briefly summarize your Chinese experience then.
I don't really have anything.
I don't have the bitterness that so many of the people that were over there had.
My comment would be very friendly toward the Chinese.
They were more polite than I ever could be.
One of my officers that I was with told me that one of the differences in culture between China and America was the fact that Chinese did not
give negative answers, and that you had to be smart enough to know when a no was a yes, or when a yes was a no.
And many Americans couldn't stand the lie that their counterpart.
And I never had any problem with it, but I'm convinced that liaison officers were destroyed in combat
because they wouldn't go along with this idea of having to make that decision.
And they'd talk to the Chinese about lying and whatever and whatever and whatever.
And they'd walk down a trail and they'd say, well, we've got to have a new liaison officer.
And how long were you over there?
Well, I got to Burma.

I got to Bombay on the 2nd of June and I was in Calcutta for two days and then I went from Calcutta to the headquarters in in Burma within two days after we got to Calcutta and I got there maybe the 15th
before I got down to my final assignment on the 22nd.
And that's 1944?
That's right.
And you're in the Far East until when?
I flew out of Burma in an airplane with four Mews on Christmas Day, 1944.
And I
was flown into China because the Japanese were threatening the last airport that the Americans had in China.
They had already captured all the rest of them.
But then this last airport was very important.
And we went down there about the 15th of April.
And on the 8th of May, we were entering combat.
We heard about the German surrender.
The Japanese started moving back.
They had put a group of soldiers on top of a mountain, sometimes two miles or three miles from the canyon.
The Chinese had to eradicate those groups up there.
regimented commander took me up to the top of a mountain that they had captured.
And there was a hundred dead Japanese on that mountain, unburied, when we got there.
And that was one of the most horrifying sights I've ever seen.
Dead soldiers and smell and so forth.
Chinese removed their dead.
and buried them.
How did you and your colleagues know that the war in the Far East was over?
How did you learn that?
Well, I was in Chickaya, in that canyon, about 20 miles down the canyon.
And when I heard about the negotiations for the surrender, I went to the headquarters.
and said, look, when am I going home?
Because I had more points than enough to go home.
And they say, oh, you've been frozen.
You're going to Nanking.
And on the 2nd of September, we were standing beside an airplane.
And whenever the official notice came that the Japanese had surrendered, we got on that airplane.
Four officers and
maybe seven enlisted men, and flew to Nanking.
And I was working on the airport at Nanking from the time that, from let's say the 3rd of September until after the surrender on Double Ten Day, October the 10th.
I never had, I was actually very fond of,
the regimental commander that I served with from the time we left the position back in the jungle.
Colonel Lee was a very fine man.
That's L-I?
L-E-E, way I'd pronounce it.
No, but it's spelled.
Probably L-I.
And I did more
I played bridge with Generalissimo, not Generalissimo, the commanding general of the 22nd Division many times.
While we were back, when we weren't in combat, I played bridge a lot.
I spent a lot of time writing to my people.
And we were told to destroy anything that we had received.
before we moved out.
And so my daughter was born on the 21st of October, and I didn't know that she was here until the 10th day of November.
And there was a squadron of, I mean, a unit of L-5 airplanes, little airplanes that delivered things all over the country.
And they'd come by and say, what are you doing today?
And I said, oh, I don't have anything to do.
So they said, come go with me.
And I went all over Central Vermont while they were airdropping mail to units or whatever.
And one time I looked up like that and there was the Irrawaddy River right up there.
That guy was flying upside down.
And then he started down.
And he made a lot of speed.
But when he got to the ground, the dust came up around us.
And all of his buddies came over there to find out why we crashed.
And when he got out of that airplane, his hand was shaking so much he couldn't light his cigarette.
He was going to scare me, and he did.
But I enjoyed flying.
And after I married,
I dreamed about flying those.
I could fly those as well in my dreams as any of them could over there.
But I didn't really have anything that made me bitter about the Chinese.
Alright, what about the Japanese?
How did you and your colleagues feel about the Japanese?
Well, we didn't like the Japanese.
They called my name on the
next day after I joined my unit and said that Major McNeil is with the 64th Regiment and he is not a part of the Chinese Army, he's a spy.
And if we capture him, we'll treat him as a spy.
Now, how, they called you on the radio or what?
No, they, Tokyo Rose called.
Tokyo Rose, okay.
Somebody was keeping them well informed about whatever happened in Burma.
Did you hear that broadcast?
See, I had a liaison team with me.
I didn't have a radio, but they had a radio and they listened to Tokyo Rose and that's what they told me the next day.
I have the impression that those men who fought in World War II in Europe have a far more positive opinion today about
their German opponents than do the Americans who fought in the Pacific have about their Japanese opponents.
I don't quite understand your statement.
The veterans of your generation who fought against the Germans don't dislike them nearly as much as the veterans who fought against the Japanese.
That's right.
Why?
Well, the Japanese have no concept
of anything but brutality.
If they captured an American officer in Burma, they hanged him immediately.
If you read about the story of the rape of Nanking, you understand the mentality of the Japanese.
Did you see some of those results personally?
Not when I got to Nanking.
It had been years before.
No, but I'm talking about did you see some of their cruelty anywhere else?
Well, I don't know that I did, but I also heard so much about them that I despised the Japanese.
How did they treat the Chinese?
They treated them very badly.
And on one occasion, a unit of battalions
was ordered to capture the top of a hill.
They made 11 assaults to the top of the hill and were not successful.
And the regimental commander went over to see what the problem was.
And he executed the commander of that battalion and took charge of it.
And he captured the top of that hill.
But there were only 79 soldiers that were alive on top of that hill out of a battalion of 700 or 800 men.
And when I questioned them about it, they said, well, our soldiers are fatalists.
I don't know whether that's the right word or not.
But said if they got wounded, they got sent to a hospital.
If they got killed,
They didn't have to fight anymore.
And the Chinese word that applies to that is Meoganchi.
What does it matter?
And I really had a good command of the Chinese language when I was with them.
Right.
Do you remember your reaction when you heard about the first atomic bombs?
I didn't know anything about it, but Wirtz told me after we got to China that they were working on it.
Now, Wirtz was in the office of General Hershey, and so he knew things that I didn't know.
All right, but what about when you all heard that it had been dropped on Japan?
I wanted to go home.
What next?
You heard about the surrender, and how long was it after you heard about the surrender before things began to change and you all knew that you would get to go home?
Well, we went to Nanking on the second day of September.
And we knew that we would be able to go home when we completed our mission.
When we completed our mission, there was no supply people there.
And the arms that I had carried, I gave to the Chinese.
And they in turn gave me sabers.
that were captured from the Japanese officers.
I have one out in my garage, and I gave one to my son who went to Vietnam.
And he lost his when the house burned that he was living in.
It doesn't look like much now, but I've got the Japanese saber yet.
All right, so in September, and then when did you get home?
Well, I left.
Nan King spent a day or two in Shanghai as a way station to Kunming.
And I stayed two or three days in Kunming and flew into Calcutta.
And I stayed in Calcutta for two or three weeks.
And they had a ship that was in there.
And they filled it up.
They had so many rooms in that ship that were for field grade officers.
And they came and said, now every one of the rooms designated for field grade officers have been taken.
They said, you can sign up to go home on enlisted men's quarters, but you need to go see where it'll be.
And I said, look, where is the list to sign?
that you'd go home on enlisted men quarters.
I didn't go look at it.
And I came home in the stairwell of, they had a bunk, in the stairwell, and I slept in that bunk.
So when did you get home?
Fifth day of December.
Right.
Describe seeing family and other loved ones
Well, I had given Colonel Miller a letter when he was in charge of the airport after we took it over.
And Colonel Miller came to the airport, and I was the person that he saw.
And I want you to know he really was unhappy about what was going on at Nanking, and he unloaded on me.
And I want you to know that that was one of the times that a major unloaded on a colonel.
And he came back, I said, take my Jeep.
And when he came back, he said, Major, I owe you an apology.
Said, you're the only person in Nanking that's doing what they're supposed to be doing.
And he later came back and was in, we got real well acquainted.
One day,
He asked me to go eat in the headquarters of his uni.
And at that time, he made some snide remark about the Kitty Corps.
And I said, Colonel Miller, what about your wife living in Alvin?
He said, oh, how do you know that?
And I said, well,
Your wife and my wife are good friends.
And I wrote a letter for him to bring to my wife because he said, I'll be flying a war-weary airplane home and be there in a week.
And he carried that letter.
We went home on the same ship.
And he carried that letter in his pocket.
And when we got to Seattle, I got in line to call James.
And I stayed in that line for 10 hours, missed my evening meal.
And I called Jane, and I said, Jane, we're here.
I'm in Seattle.
She said, I know that.
Colonel Miller's wife told me that three years ago.
You know how, well, you don't know.
But it was not anything it could have been.
affected me the way that did.
I got into San Antonio, checked in, went to spend the night with one of Jane's relatives, got back in there the next morning, and he walked in after I was halfway through processing.
And I said, Colonel Miller, have you still got that letter?
And he said, yes, I have, and I'm going to give it to your wife.
And he did.
But he carried it all the way.
He said, I got grounded on an airplane in Mountain Home in Idaho and said we were snowed in for that long and said I have got that letter for her.
So when did you get back to Alvin?
Well, I guess about the 6th or 7th of
of December.
And if I remember correctly, we had bought this farm.
And as soon as I got home, we came first to Moody, and Jane had rented a house in Moody, an apartment.
And I came to Moody within two or three days from the time I left San Antonio.
All right, so you were then, very soon you were on inactive duty?
That's right.
And I stayed in the reserve.
What were you planning to do as a civilian?
I was going to be on this farm for the rest of my life.
And I was going to be the rural carrier for Moody because that was the best job they had in Moody.
All right.
Take the story from there.
back to A&M?
Well, I taught in the McClendon County Vocational School for four years.
And I was gone from home and so much.
And finally, I went into partnership with one of the veterans.
And while I was in that partnership, I hurt my back and went to Dallas and spent from Thanksgiving Day, 1947
1950 to 15th of March 1950.
And when I got home, I knew that I had just less than three months to get into the veterans training program.
So I went to A&M on the 1st of June and enrolled.
Because July the 15th was the date that you had to make.
And left the kids here.
My wife took me to Marlin every morning.
I went to A&M and stayed until Friday and came back.
She met me in Marlin sometime Friday afternoon or Saturday morning.
How had A&M changed since you left it?
And those...
eight years or so?
Well, the biggest change was the fact that A&M was flooded with veterans.
And they told a story that I told my class.
And this story was that they put all of the
all of the Army veterans out at Bryan Air Force Base.
And they had a prof that went out to the Air Corps base to teach classes.
And he'd go out there and get his room ready to preach and put his hat on the table.
And when they put his hat on the table, then he'd go to one of the mess halls and drink coffee with the mess sergeant.
And he was late coming back.
And when he got back, there wasn't anybody in the room.
They swapped him.
And so the next day, when they came back in, there was a big sign on the front of the door on the wall.
I gave a test yesterday and all of you made zero.
And they started howling.
And he said, well, that's the way it is.
You walk my class.
And when he came to the classroom the next day, the hat, there was a hat on every room.
And I told my class that.
Have you heard that story before?
And I want you to know that I kept an accurate record of attendance while I was at A&M.
And I never had a class to walk me while I was teaching.
I was on the program one time and the graduate student was supposed to teach my class, but he forgot and they walked him, but they never walked me while I taught.
Now you enrolled in 1950 and what was your goal in terms of a degree at that point?
Well, I had already
